newsitem.title: JAPAN: N. Korea says religious figure defects from South.
newsitem.headline: N. Korea says religious figure defects from South.

text.p: A man described as a major South Korean religious figure has defected to North Korea, official North Korean media was quoted as saying on Saturday.

The Tokyo based RadioPress news agency quoted the state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) as saying that O Ik-je, the leader until 1995 of the 130-year old Chandogyo religious group, arrived in Pyongyang on Friday but did not say when he had defected from the south, RadioPress reported. A South Korean government run news agency quoted KCNA as saying he was a member of the main opposition National Congress for New Politics.
A spokewoman for the party in Seoul said O was a member but could not confirm the KCNA report that he had defected.
O gave a speech on his arrival at Pyongyang's train station slamming South Korean president Kim Young-sam and praising the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il, Radio Press quoted KCNA as saying.
"I have not shirked from doing my best towards the peaceful reunification of the motherland by opposing this facist presidency which is against reunification", KCNA quoted O as saying.

"I wanted to defect many years ago but until now I could not fulfill this desire," O added. "It is the highest honour to come to this great society guided by Kim Jong-il... and I wish to uphold the principle of unification of the nation made clear by the great leader Kim Il-sung."
